json.text: Lost in unfamiliar territory with no way of getting help...stranded and left to die alone...here
we present to you 8 people who got lost on a trip and died.
Number 8: Geraldine Largay July, 2013: while on a trip to the Appalachian
Trails with her husband, 66-year-old Geraldine Largay went off the track to relieve herself.
She was supposed to meet her husband at an entrance to the trail just north of Carrabassett
Valley.
But she got lost and never found her way back.
In a text message to her husband of 42 years, she said that she was in trouble.
She got lost after going to the bathroom, and needed her husband to get a trail maintainer
to help her escape the woods.
The following days she sent similar text messages asking her husband to get police help.
Sadly, none of those messages got through due to poor reception.
Extensive searches were made in the initial days and weeks of her disappearance, scouring
the areas where she might be, but they never found her.
At least not alive.
Two years later in October 2015, a logger in the area discovered a tent with human remains,
later confirmed to be Geraldine Largay.
Among the items found alongside her, was a diary in a black composition book detailing
her experience.
Knowing her deabt to be imminent, she wrote down asking for her husband and daughter to
be notified of her deabt, and to have the contents of her backpack sent to them.
Searchers said that the area they found her remains had been searched, but it is unsure
how they missed her back then.
Number 7: David and Ornella Steiner August, 2015: rangers at the White Sands National
Monument in New Mexico find French couple David Steiner and his wife Ornella dead, presumably
from dehydration.
They initially spotted Ornella and later found their 9 year old son Enzo badly sun burnt
but alive next to his father's corpse.
Two empty 17 ounce water bottles were also found, which is much less than the gallon
of water recommended for visitors to bring.
It is believed that the couple sacrificed themselves by giving their son the only water
they had.
Images from the wife's camera revealed that the couple and their son had been hiking across
the desert during midday in temperatures well above one hundred degrees Fahrenheit.
It is presumed that the couple had simply underestimated the elements of the desert.
The young Enzo was taken to a nearby hospital.
He claimed that his father had became disoriented and his tongue swollen.
His father kept insisting that a truck was nearby even though they were more than a mile
into the trail.
It was also presumed that his mother exacerbated a previous knee injury on the journey.
The Steiners' debt marked the third and fourth debt in the park in the past 10 years.
Number 6: Ondrej Petr July, 2016: Czech couple Ondrej Petr and Pavlina
Pizova set off for Routeburn Track; the world renowned tramping track in New Zealand.
They informed no one of their plans and brought no tent or locator beacons.
Despite warnings of bad weather from staff of the Department of Conservation (DOC), the
couple went on with their plans.
After spending one night out in the open at the Falls hut, the pair got caught in freezing
weather and became disoriented.
Heavy fog accompanied by strong winds and snow caused them to slip five to seven meters
down a steep slope.
Petr fell further and got trapped between vegetations and rocks.
His girlfriend was able to reach him but was unable to free him.
Exhausted after trying everything she could; she finally heard his final gasps of dying
breath.
Luckily, Pizova did not share the same fate as her boyfriend.
After spending a couple of nights in sub-zero temperature, and another few days hiking she
reached an empty campsite.
Unable to escape the deep snow, she decided to wait patiently, surviving on whatever supplies
she could find at the campsite.
After four weeks, a helicopter crew picked her up and sent her to the hospital.
Petr's remains were also recovered, and sent to his family in Czech Republic.
Number 5: Devin Williams In May 1995, long haul truck driver Devin
Williams headed to California for one of his routine shipment deliveries.
But the husband and father of three from Lyon County, Kansas was never seen again by his
family.
After California, Williams headed to Kansas City after picking up another cargo for delivery.
But his next sighting was very unusual.
Williams’ ten ton truck was seen crashing through the woods at Arizona’s Tonto National
Forest, coming frighteningly close to hitting two nearby campers.
After coming to a stop, witnesses saw a disoriented Williams coming out, mumbling incoherent phrases
like "they made me do it" and "I’m going to jail".
Williams quickly abandoned the scene on foot, and by the time police arrived he was nowhere
to be found.
Williams' strange behavior prompted suspicions of drug use or mental illness, although he
never had any prior history related to those problems.
His disappearance raised many questions and speculations including one involving aliens
by conspiracy theorists.
Nearly two years later, hikers found a human skull half a mile from where his truck crashed.
Dental records confirmed it to be Devin Williams, but the questions surrounding his behavior,
disappearance, and cause of debt remains unanswered.
Number 4: Donald Crowhurst In 1968, British sailor Donald Crowhurst decided
to enter the Sunday Times Golden Globe Boat Race, history’s first ever round the world
yacht race.
A nautical technocrat himself, Crowhurst spent nearly all his money building a catamaran
he was certain would easily outperform other competitors.
Unfortunately for him, the venture went on a series of delays and misfortunes, causing
the vessel to barely be finished on time and Crowhurst had to set sail without much preparation.
Facing financial ruin, he gambled everything he had on winning the race, giving himself
only 50/50 odds of surviving.
The untested vessel soon became badly holed, and when the hopelessness of his voyage set
in, the desperate Crowhurst decided to fake his logs.
Crowhurst provided a steady stream of fabricated reports, and illegally landed in north Argentina
to patch up the hull.
However, all his radio transmissions ended suddenly on June 29th, 1969.
His vessel was found adrift on July 10 in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, empty except
for his logbook containing increasingly deranged writings.
He had scribbled down over 25,000 words of false navigational entries, poems, philosophy,
and random thoughts.
It is believed that the stress had broken him, causing him to go insane and lose his
way at sea before eventually jumping overboard to his debt.
Number 3: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon In March 2014, students Kris Kremers and Lisanne
Froon arrived in Panama for a six week vacation on a flight from Amsterdam.
After two weeks in the country, the Dutch students decided for a hike near a local volcano
in the small town of Boquete.
The pair left without a guide and without notifying precisely which trail they were
taking.
Their only other companion was a Husky mix named "Blue" that belonged to the hostel they
were staying in.
The dog returned to the town, but sadly, the girls did not.
10 days after their disappearance, their body parts were found including bone fragments.
More of their possessions including a phone and camera were found after another 10 weeks.
The phone recorded attempted calls for 911 just hours after they left for the hike, and
the camera had captured many flash photos in complete darkness of the jungle, most of
them were taken one week after their disappearance.
According to local investigators, the most likely scenario was that one of the girls
wandered off the trail and somehow got herself injured.
The other girl then tried to help and was also injured.
Unfortunately, without food and water, it was only a matter of time until the elements
took their toll.
Number 2: Xavier Mertz In December 1912, Swiss ski champion Xavier
Mertz took part in the "Australian Antarctic Expedition", an expedition focusing on scientific
researches in the Antarctic continent between 1911 and 1914.
Mertz who specialized in glacier and mountain formations would become part of a 3 man team
called the "Far Eastern Party".
The team was tasked to investigate the previously unexplored coastal regions of Antarctica,
west of Cape Adare.
But their mission proved ill fated.
More than 311 miles from base, a member of the team fell through the snow lid of a crevasse,
taking the supply sled with him.
Mertz was left wondering the snow desert alone with Australian explorer Douglas Mawson.
Their supplies now reduced to almost nothing, the pair attempted to head back, and gradually
shot their remaining sled dogs for food to supplement their scarce rations.
On a diet of butchered sled dog livers, Mertz's skin sloughed off from vitamin A poisoning.
He became severely ill before he finally died on January 8th, 1913, almost a week after
making little headway.
Recently, some modern historians accuse Mawson of intentionally reducing their rations, believing
himself to be fit enough to outlast a slowly starving Mertz.
Returning to camp as a hero, Mawson reported that Mertz had raved incoherently and called
"Oh dear, oh dear" for hours.
Number 1: Masha On the eve of 2005, a young Ukrainian teenage
girl named Masha went out with her friends for a New Years Eve party.
They headed into the Odessa Catacombs; an old network of tunnels formed in the 19th
century as a result of stone mining, which was later used for smuggling and as a hideout
for rebel groups and criminals.
The pitch black tunnels twist and turn over 1500 miles, and the full extent of their topography
is still unknown.
Everyone was enjoying themselves at the 2005 New Years Eve party, drinking and having fun.
But at some point in the night Masha made the mistake of trying to explore the catacombs
by herself.
She quickly became separated from her group of partiers, and got completely lost.
All by herself in the dark, the girl was doomed to helplessly wander the catacombs in a futile
attempt to escape.
Despite a massive search that was launched, no one was able to find her in the massively
long unmapped tunnels.
It wasn't until two years later that police finally found her body in 2007.
Because of the cool air, the body seemed to have been partially mummified.
It is believed that after 3 days of desperate exploration, she broke down from exhaustion
and lied of dehydration.

of the links below.
